Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Monetary DSGE Models at the Zero Lower Bound: Policy Analysis and Econometric Inference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds research in macroeconomics, focusing on the development of tools and methods for building and testing mathematical models of an entire economy. The goal is to better understand how economies operate when nominal interest rates are very close or equal to zero; standard models use mathematical assumptions that do not work well with 0% interest. These challenges limit the ability of researchers to study the causes of business cycle fluctuations when an economy is near this interest rate. Because policymakers use some of the same modeling methods, the challenges also affect policymakers' ability to understand the possible effects of changes in monetary policy. The PIs will develop new algorithms and methods for modeling economies with 0% interest.

The PIs will examine monetary policy analysis at the Zero Lower Bound (ZLB), considering the effects of forward guidance at the ZLB and characterizing the optimal target inflation rate when the ZLB is a constraint and there are also realistic frictions that generate money demand. They will consider the multiple equilibrium problem caused by impose the ZLB in many DSGE models by considering two specific equilibria, one in which inflation and inflation expectations drift slowly, and one where the change in regimes is triggered by fundamental shocks. Finally, the team will develop two kinds of nonlinear vector autoregressive models that mimic the nonlinearities in the DSGE model without imposing tight cross-coefficient restrictions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When we started the project, Japan had experienced near-zero interest rates and a deflation of about minus one percent since the late 1990s. In the U.S. the federal funds rate, which is the key interest rate controlled by the Federal Reserve, dropped below 20 basis points in December 2008 and had stayed near zero in the aftermath of the Great Recession through the end of 2015. Investor's access to currency, which yields a zero nominal return, prevents interest rates from falling (significantly) below zero and thereby creates a zero lower bound (ZLB) - or an effective lower bound (ELB) - for nominal interest rates.

The ZLB constrains conventional monetary policy responses, i.e., lowering of the policy interest rates, to adverse shocks. This inability to stabilize the economy is a major concern of central bankers. Moreover, the recent experiences of the U.S. and Japan have raised concern among policy makers about a long-lasting switch to a regime in which interest rates are zero, inflation is low, and conventional macroeconomic policies are less effective. One of the questions that we asked in our project is, whether the U.S. and Japan had been pushed into a new regime, in which the central bank is not able to achieve its inflation target anymore.

It turns out, that a careful analysis of this question is complicated. Starting point was a standard quantitative macroeconomic model with a role for stabilization policy. Prior to 2009, at least for the U.S., such a model would have been analyzed without imposing a ZLB constraint on the nominal interest rate. Even though the model is nonlinear, an approximation using linear equations is fairly accurate. However, once the ZLB is imposed the analysis becomes more complicated: (i) linear equations no longer suffice to describe the evolution of the macro economy; (ii) the macroeconomic outcomes are no longer unique: using the same assumptions about the preferences of households and firms and the behavior of the central bank, different outcomes are possible. For instance, it could be that inflation rates are close to target or it could be that inflation rates are negative.

Against this backdrop, the research funded under our grant, developed new techniques to construct nonlinear solutions to macroeconomic models; to characterize the various outcomes (or equilibria) that the model can generate; and to confront the model with data to infer whether the U.S. or Japan had transitioned to a regime in which inflation is permanently low and the central bank consistently misses its inflation target. The results are somewhat sensitive to the details of the model specification, but on balance the answer is affirmative for Japan and negative for the U.S.

The image that is part of this report provides some flavor of how a formal analysis of this question is conducted. Our mathematical model of the macroeconomy can generate two regimes. In the targeted inflation regime the central bank approximately achieves its inflation target - not exactly because the economy is constantly exposed to shocks. In the deflationary regime, nominal interest rates are close to zero and inflation rates are, with high probability, negative. The contours in the images indicate combinations of interest and inflation rates that are highly likely according to the model. The dots and stars indicate actual realization. If the actual realizations fall into a region that is deemed likely by the model, then the theory provides a good explanation. From the figure it is difficult to infer whether the interest and inflation rate observations are more likely conditional on the deflation regime or the targeted-inflation regime for the U.S.and Japan, which is why we had to develop more elaborate statistical techniques to arrive at our final results.

Macroeconomic models that are used for the analysis described above impose strong restrictions on how GDP growth, employment, inflation, interest rates and other macroeconomic variables can evolve over time. Thus, it is important to have tools that enable the assessment of such model, i.e., their success in capturing salient features of the data. While there are many of these tools available for linear macroeconomic models, there are very few tools for the evaluation of nonlinear models. Our research developed new tools that can be used to determine whether the nonlinearities hardwired into the macro models are actually consistent with the data.

Central banks use macroeconomic models to generate forecasts which then inform policy decisions. Our project documented how certain model features contribute to the accuracy of the forecasts. We also examined techniques that allow policy makers to combine forecasts from multiple models in an efficient manner.

Finally, our project developed a variety of new computational tools to confront macroeconomic models with data. These tools are also useful for other research areas.
